text: number 29 this evening, Genesis chapter number 29, and I mentioned last week as we were taking our path through the first section of Genesis 29, really looking at verses 1 through 30, and in that study we traced the steps of Jacob as he arrived to Haran, and it's interesting because we noted in verse number 1 of Genesis 29, the Bible says, then Jacob went on his journey, and I made the statement that the journey continues, and what a blessing to read about the experience that Jacob had at the end of Genesis 28, and the Lord appearing to him, and the Lord speaking to him, and his commitments to God, and setting up the altar there at Bethel, and what a blessing to read about that experience, and the impact of that experience that he had, but the journey continues, and I kind of likened it to our own lives, and how we can think about that day of our salvation when we recognized our need for Christ, and he saved our soul, and then we continue our journey, and we know that Jacob's journey ends as we read of his death later on here in the book of Genesis, and our journey, too, will end one day, but as we journey with the Lord, that we'd be mindful of the importance of keeping our eyes on him, and keeping our eyes on Jesus. Hebrews chapter number 12 says, looking unto Jesus, the author and finisher of our faith, and I'm so thankful this evening that he has provided us with instruction. Just as Jacob would deal with adversity, and hardships, and interactions with people that were kind, and people that were not so kind, and all of the things that he would deal with, we, too, have a variety of interactions that we face in life. As we wrapped up Genesis 29, the first section, verses 1-30 last week, we left off where Jacob ended the text of Scripture with two brides, Leah and Rachel, and as we think about the word of God, and we think about what God has provided us with, really, as we've studied through the book of Genesis, it's been a long time, this is message number 67, in fact, of preaching through the book of Genesis, and I've thoroughly enjoyed it, I trust that you have as well, and as we look here at these next several, really, I'm probably going to split this into two weeks of lessons of messages, but as we begin this evening looking at the sons of Jacob, we will begin to navigate through this section of Scripture, and read of how God blessed, and God built this family, and we understand there's many just discussions that take place in this passage of Scripture, and you begin to think about the carnality that's present, you think about the competition that is evidenced, and you see all of these things, but I believe that as we study through this passage of Scripture, and we trace through this passage, I believe that there's a lesson for us to learn here. I believe that as you go through and study the names, in particular, of the sons of Jacob, you will be able to note, not only through the names of the sons, but through the dialogue that is given, that there is a real conflict between Leah and Rachel, and we've mentioned in previous messages of having dysfunctional families, and looking at the dysfunctional families here in Genesis already that we've looked to, and mentioning how that in our society, still today, there are many dysfunctional families, and I'm thankful that God has given us a book that gives us instruction with regard to the home, and how a family is supposed to operate, and what God's design is for the home. But as we note, as you go through the passage of Scripture, you see the conflict, and I believe that the conflict is most easily evidenced and really traced through the names of the sons, and the significance of their names, and really the dialogue, and what takes place. And so, of course, you know that there are twelve sons, and that's why I think it's going to take us two weeks to get through it. There are twelve sons, and of course, they would become the twelve tribes of Israel, and we're mindful of that, and we understand as you begin to look at the whole of the history that God provides us with in the Old Testament, with regard to His people, the children of Israel, and you think about the tribes, and obviously you look here to the fulfillment of what God said to Abraham with regard to the promise of a seed and a land, and then of course that promise was given to Isaac, and then reiterated to Jacob as we studied in a previous message, where God had given him the instruction with regard to the blessing of a large family. As we begin reading in verse number 31 of Genesis 29, and we look at this first section or this first of two messages on the sons of Jacob, notice the Bible says this in verse 31, and when the Lord saw that Leah was hated, He opened her womb, but Rachel was barren, and Leah conceived and bare a son, and she called His name Reuben, and she said, Surely the Lord hath looked upon my affliction, now therefore my husband will love me. And she conceived again and bare a son, and said, Because the Lord hath heard that I was hated, He hath therefore given me this son also. And she called His name Simeon, and she conceived again, verse 34, and bare a son, and said, Now this time will my husband be joined unto me, because I have borne him three sons, therefore was his name called Levi. And she conceived again and bare a son, and she said, Now will I praise the Lord, therefore she called His name Judah, and left bearing. As we look at the sons of Jacob, I want you to see in verse number 32, the first of these sons is Reuben. The Bible tells us that she conceived in verse number 32, and that she bare a son, and she called his name Reuben. The name Reuben really, it carries with it the idea of this, behold a son. You think about the significance of the families and understanding in the culture, the significance of having a son, and the importance of having a son, and you find here that right at the beginning, when we find that Reuben is born, that Leah would name Reuben, behold a son. That's what the name means. And when you think about the phraseology and understanding the significance of having a son, and I want you to see what she says here in this text of Scripture, it says this in verse number 32, for she said, Surely the Lord hath looked upon my affliction. Again, it gives us evidence to this conflict that was brewing between Leah and Rachel, and we'll continue to see this as we trace through the names of these sons and through this text of Scripture. And then I want you to notice the end of verse number 32. Notice what she says, now therefore my husband will love me. She had the belief, she had the expectation that because she had had a son and because she had given in her mind this son to Jacob and the significance of having a son, that this would change the dynamic in the family and that the circumstances would be more favorable for her, and now she would be loved by Jacob. You see that she has high expectations. She has full anticipation that this would be the case, and we see the significance and the confidence that she has. Surely the Lord hath looked upon my affliction. You know that God sees everything.
